bibl.title: Letter from Henry M. Hurd to Howard A. Kelly, November 13, 1905

div1.p: Hurd writes with suggestions for changes to Kelly's manuscript on the life of Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Henry M. Hurd to Howard A. Kelly, November 13, 1905
div1.opener:
Form 135-10,000-5-31-1905.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
THE JOHNS HOPKINS HOSPITAL,
NORTH BROADWAY.
Baltimore, November, 13th, 1905 190
HENRY M. HURD, M. D.
Superintendent.
Dear Dr. Kelly:--
div1.p:
I have gone over the Reed manuscript very care-
fully, and find it admirable even in its present imperfect form. When
it is fully prepared for the press, I should like to look over it again,
not with the idea of making corrections as to form and style (I think
too much of that has already been done by Miss Scott), but with the
idea of making certain suggestions as to omissions and additions. I
would now make the following suggestions:

1. Omit all names where Reed in private letters speaks dis-
paragingly, critically or freely of other physicians. To
publish the names of Sternberg, Guiteras and others can
only wound and injure his memory without doing any good.

2. I think it should be noted that Dr. Reed left his work in
Dr. Welch's laboratory to go west to Minnesota, and was
present at the Battle of Wounded Knee, where the Ghost
Dancers had stirred up a serious rebellion. I am sure
that he wrote some graphic account of his experiences then.
I know that he told of them in a most interesting way.
The spirit and energy which he displayed at that time show-
ed that laboratory work did not unfit a man for the active
duties of an army surgeon.

3. I would mention Reed's great anxiety at the outbreak of
the Spanish-American War to hold some responsible position

#2.
in charge of sick soldiers. He knew that his experience
had fitted him to undertake this work, and was familiar
with the conditions of the army, the routine of getting
supplies, the manner of preserving the health of soldiers,
and general management, practical matters which were un-
known to civilian physicians and political doctors who
were appointed to responsible positions over him. He made
a strong effort to secure some responsible position, for
which years of army work had admirably fitted him, and
was chagrined and distressed that men with political pull
were preferred, while he and other practical army surgeons
were relegated to other unimportant positions.

4. In a conversation with me after the War was over, he spoke
with extreme sadness of the fact that, by such mismanagement
on the part of the Secretary of War and others who should
have known better, the Army Medical Corps had been subjected
to a censure which it did not deserve. To use his own
words, “the Army Medical Corps received a “black eye” be-
cause of the neglect and incompetence of men who really
did not belong to it.”

5. In the Yellow Fever chapter I would add a full account of
the late epidemic at New Orleans, in order to complete the
yellow fever history and as an illustration of the way in
which the epidemic was controlled by due attention to the

#3.
facts brought out by Reed's “mosquito theory”.

6. I think also I would give a full account of the methods em-
ployed in New Orleans to destroy mosquitoes and to screen
cisterns, and for historical completeness I would add some
account of the present method of treating the disease.
There is every reason to think that the epidemic was more
successfully treated in New Orleans during the past summer
than any previous epidemic. The mortality was smaller and
the convalescence of patients who survived was more speedy.
Local physicians insisted that these improved conditions
were due to improved methods of treatment.

7. I would give an account of the work of the Typhoid Commiss-
ion composed of Reed, as Chairman, Shakespeare and Vaughan.
Upon this Commission Reed did most important work, as shown
by the late elaborate report which has appeared under the
names of Reed, Shakespeare and Vaughan, although finally
written by Vaughan. There must be some record in the Army
Reports of the amount of preliminary work which Reed did. I
know he went about extensively, visiting camps and also col-
lected a large amount of material.

8. I think also there should be in the volume somewhere, prob-
ably at the end, a strong appeal for the reorganization of
the Army Medical Corps, in the light of experiences in Cuba.
In Cuba, it will be remembered, the Army Medical Corps in

#4.
hygienic and sanitary matters was entirely subordinated to
the will of ignorant, incompetent or indifferent military
officers. The Army Surgeon could recommend, but he had
no authority to carry out his recommendations. This, in
fact, was General Sternberg's excuse for permitting disease
to ravage the camps -- that he was powerless to enforce clean
camps, good drinking water and adequate sanitary arrangements
because of the lack of co-operation on the part of the mili-
tary men. These things could only be secured when the mili-
tary commander was willing to order the work to be done. If
he was not willing, the surgeon had no power.

9. I think it would be well to publish a chapter containing an
account of the meetings held at North East Harbor, Washing-
ton and elsewhere to raise funds for a statue and for the
family of Dr. Reed. Some of the best men of the nation
spoke and co-operated in the movement, and I think it would
be of great interest to have a statement of the fact.

In conclusion, I would add that I have been much interested
in your book, and I congratulate you upon its success in its present
form. I believe that the book will do a lot of good.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Henry M. Hurd add ref to Nuttalls appreciation in Jour. Hygiene
